description: Processed raw data as used for the quantitative analysis of the response of the barley root plasma membrane to salinity stress. Three replicates were analyzed for both each treatment and each genotype. Proteins were either digested with trypsin or elastase. Protein separation was performed by means of reversed phase chromatography on a BEH 130 column (1,7µm, 100 mm x 100 µm) coupled to a trap column for desalting (Symmetry 5µm, 20mm x 180 µm) and using a nanoLC-ESI-QTOF-MS system (Q-TOF Premier, Waters) according to Kaspar et al. (2010). Data processing and data base searches were performed using PLGS GlobalServer software vs. 2.3. Quantitative protein analysis was later on performed using the LC-MS Progenesis software (Nonlinear Dynamics).
keywords: plasma membrane, hordeum vulgare, protein analysis, salinity stress
name: Processed raw data as used for the quantitative analysis of the response of the barley root plasma membrane to salinity stress

description: Whole rapeseeds were scanned using a high resolution X-ray micro-CT system. The X-ray shadow projections of the 3-D object were digitized as 2048 x 2048 pixel images and were processed to obtain reconstructed cross-section images using a mathematical algorithm based on the filtered back-projection procedure implemented in the NRecon 1.6.2.0 software. This resulted in a 3-D stack of 1500 virtual sections, each consisting of 1500 × 1500 isotropic voxels of (1.7 µm3) with a linear X-ray attenuation coefficient, displayed as a grey scale value calibrated between 0 and 255. This movie shows a complete scan of the developing seed of Brassica napus. Developmental stage corresponds to the main storage phase (about 30 days after fertilization)
keywords: developing seed, Brassica napus, Micro CT, virtual sections
name: Animated movie of the high-resolution CT images of the developing Brassica napus seed

description: Acquired raw data as used for the protein identification of differential spots from the quantitative analysis of the response of the barley root proteome to salinity stress. Acquisition of peptide mass fingerprint data was performed on a Reflex III MALDI-TOF device (Bruker Daltonics, Bremen, Germany, www.bruker.com/) operating in reflector mode using the FlexControl software. Spectra were calibrated using external calibration, with subsequent internal mass correction. Protein identification was performed with the Mascot search engine (Matrix Science, London, United Kingdom, www.matrixscience.com/home.html), by searching the barley EST (expressed sequence tag) Gene Index in the TIGR database (compbio.dfci.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/tgi/gimain.pl?gudb=barley) and the HarvEST database (harvest.ucr.edu/). Parameters for the search were: monoisotopic mass accuracy 100 ppm tolerance, missed cleavages 1, allowed variable modifications: oxidation (Met), propionamide (Cys) and carbamidomethyl (Cys). When this approach failed, the samples were subjected to analysis by nanoLC-ESI-Q-TOF MS/MS and de novo sequencing (nanoLC ESI-Q-TOF MS/MS, Waters Corporation, Milford, USA, www.waters.com), following Amme et al. (2006) using the MassLynx software. A 10 ppm peptide, 0.1 Da fragment tolerance, one missed cleavage and variable oxidation (Met), propionamide (Cys) and carbamidomethyl (Cys) were used as the search parameters. Database searches were conducted against the barley EST Gene Index of the TIGR database and the HarvEST database.
keywords: roots, hordeum vulgare, protein analysis, salinity stress
name: Acquired raw data as used for the protein identification of differential spots from the quantitative analysis of the response of the barley root proteome to salinity stress

description: Depending on the atmospheric composition, isoprene emissions from plants can have a severe impact on air quality and regional climate. For the plant itself, isoprene can enhance stress tolerance and also interfere with the attraction of herbivores and parasitoids. Here, we tested the growth performance and fitness of Populus á canescens in which iso-prene emission had been knocked down by RNA interference technology (PcISPS-RNAi plants) for two growing seasons under outdoor conditions. Neither the growth nor biomass yield of the PcISPS-RNAi poplars was impaired, and they were even temporarily enhanced compared with control poplars. Modelling of the annual carbon balances revealed a reduced carbon loss of 2.2% of the total gross primary production by the absence of isoprene emission, and a 6.9% enhanced net growth of PcISPS-RNAi poplars. However, the knock down in isoprene emission resulted in reduced susceptibility to fungal infection, whereas the attractiveness for herbivores was enhanced. The present study promises potential for the use of non- or low-isoprene-emitting poplars for more sustainable and environmentally friendly biomass production, as reducing isoprene emission will presumably have positive effects on regional climate and air quality.
keywords: supplemental material, biomass production, modelling, non-isoprene emitting, outdoor conditions, populus x canescens
name: Supplemental material : 'Isoprene emission-free poplars - a chance to reduce the impact from poplar plantations on the atmosphere'

description: This data resource contains the Best Linear Unbiased Estimates of 135 elite winter wheat (Triticum aestivum L.) lines adapted to Central Europe and 1,604 F1 hybrids derived from them. All genotypes were evaluated for seven quality traits in up to six environments (Zhao et al. 2015; Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America 112:15624-15629; DOI: 10.1073/pnas.1514547112; Liu et al. 2016. Liu et al. 2016; PlosOne; DOI: 10.1371/journal.pone.0158635). The sedimentation (SDS) volume according to Zeleny (unit ml) providing a measure for gluten content and swelling properties and thus baking quality of wheat was determined in accordance with International Association for Cereal Science and Technology (ICC) Standards 116/1 and 118 (http://www.icc.or.at/standard_methods). Protein, gluten, and starch content (unit %) as well as hardness were determined by near infrared reflectance (NIR) spectroscopy in accordance to ICC Standard 159 (http://www.icc.or.at/standard_methods). 1000-kernel weight (unit g) and test weight (unit kg hL-1) were determined in accordance with variety registration regulations.
keywords: Bread wheat (Triticum aestivum L.), phenotypic data of quality traits, hybrids and parental inbred lines
name: Phenotypic data of seven quality traits for a population of Central European wheat hybrids and their parental inbred lines

description:
A non-redundant sequence was constructed by removing overlaps between neighboring BACs.

This FASTA file contains two kinds of sequences: (i) fragments of BAC
sequence contigs and (ii) fragments of contigs of the
whole-genome shotgun assembly of cv. Morex that harbor high-confidence
genes missing from the BAC assemblies. 

The fragment coordinates are specified in the header line of each
fragment (e.g. HVVMRXALLMA0201C17_C2:3198-6633 or
morex_contig_95399:1-9263). The coordinates are 1-based (as opposed to
0-based as in the second column of BED files).

This file contains very long lines as each contig/scaffold
sequence is printed on a single line without breaks.
keywords: barley, Hordeum vulgare, genome assembly, genome annotation, sequence resource, next-generation sequencing
name: Non-redundant sequence constructed from individual assemblies of BACs of barley cv. Morex

description: The Rye Genome Zipper uses a novel approach that incorporates chromosome sorting, second generation sequencing, array hybridization and systematic exploitation of conserved synteny with model grasses. It allows to assign 45,958 WGS contigs to individual chromosomes, containing 58% of the estimated 27,784 rye genes. The constructed 'zippers' integrate gene indices of rice (Oryza sativa L., Os), sorghum (Sorghum bicolor L., Sb) and Brachypodium (Brachypodium distachyon L., Bd) in a conserved synteny model and assemble 16,144 rye genes in a putative linear order. For a detailed description of the Genome Zipper approach see publication Mayer et al. 2009 (doi: 10.1104/pp.109.142612) and Martis et al. 2013 (doi: 10.1105/tpc.113.114553). The Rye Genome Zipper is linked to the WGS assembly (v2) of the rye genome available at EMBL/ENA under the project number PRJEB13501 with accession numbers FKKI010000001-FKKI011581707. Corresponding files provide a linear ordered, information-rich scaffold of the seven rye chromosomes. The provided Excel file (‘Summary_Statistics_of_RGZ.xlsx’) contains the number of markers and genes per chromosome that are linked in the Rye Genome Zipper.
keywords: Rye, Secale cereale L., Rye Genome Zipper version 2, RYE-Select
name: Updated version (v2) of the Rye Genome Zipper

description: Protein analysis data of the quantitative comparison of milky sap proteins from Chelidonium majus L. of the growth stage III versus stage IV. Four biological and two technical replicates have been analyzed for each stage. Proteins were digested with elastase. Protein separation was performed by means of reversed phase chromatography on a BEH 130 column (1,7µm, 100 mm x 100 µm) coupled to a trap column for desalting (Symmetry 5µm, 20mm x 180 µm) and using a nanoLC-ESI-QTOF-MS system (Q-TOF Premier, Waters) according to Kaspar et al. (2010). Data processing and data base searches were performed using PLGS GlobalServer software vs. 2.3. Quantitative protein analysis was later on performed using the LC-MS Progenesis software (v4.0, Nonlinear Dynamics). Data of 49 proteins with shifted relative abundance patterns are shown.
keywords: proteomics, Greater Celandine, latex, defense-related proteins, chemometrics
name: Protein analysis data of the quantitative comparison of milky sap proteins from Chelidonium majus L. of the growth stage III versus stage IV

description: The review (288 pages A4) contains a taxonomic treatment of subg. Melanocrommyum (82 species and subspecies with about 40 synonyms, but no new taxa) affiliated to 17 sections and 21 subsections. Included is also subg. Porphyroprason (1 species, 2 synonyms). The publication starts with a Foreword, a General Introduction into the biological features of subg. Melanocrommyum, and an illustrated key (in color) for determination simultaneously in English and Russian on opposite pages. In the Taxonomy chapter, the complete synonymy (according to the current rules of botanical nomenclature) with data of types and paratypes, the known distribution, a detailed morphological description, a plate composed of several color photographs, karyological data available from the literature and own observations, the offspring of the living material studied, taxonomic remarks (including a detailed discussion of molecular results), biological data, and economic traits are presented for every species and subspecies as far as data were available or were published in the literature. A comprehensive List of References and an Index of Scientific and Folk's names plus more general terms complete the volume. A list of herbarium vouchers seen and some original karyological data are added as appendices.
keywords: Allium subg. Melanocrommyum, Central Asia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Taxonomy, Description, Nomenclature, Key for Determination, Distribution, Morphology, Biological Data, Economic Traits, Karyology
name: A Preliminary Review of Allium subg. Melanocrommyum in Central Asia

description:
Raw data files of the metabolite profiling of red and blue potatoes for anthocyanins and other polyphenols: (i) the Bruker Daltonics LC-UV/MS raw data files, (ii) the Waters LC-MS/MRM raw data files, (iii) the integrated peak areas for 23 tentatively annotated anthocyanin peaks (according to Supplemental Figure 1g) in tuber flesh and peel, respectively, of 57 potato genotypes, and (iv) the integrated peak areas for 21 tentatively annotated anthocyanins and 31 polyphenols (according to Table 3), respectively, in tuber flesh and/or peel of 19 potato genotypes.
For LC-UV/MS based metabolite profiling flesh and peel from three tubers per cultivar where pooled. Extracts were prepared from 100 mg lyophilized ground material using two times 500 µl of a mixture of 70% methanol with 2% formic acid. The samples were weighted into a 2 ml reaction tube and after addition of the extraction solvent the tubes were vortexed for 3 s, shaken for 30 min on a thermomixer at 4°C and centrifuged for 10 min at 4°C with 28,000 g. The supernatants were transferred to fresh reaction tubes. After repetition of this procedure both supernatants were combined. For each sample two independent extracts were made to obtain two technical replicates for the LC-UV/MS profiling. For preparation of samples applied to LC-MS/MRM analysis, six tubers where pooled randomized from two to five plants per cultivar. The extraction procedure was the same as described above but using non acidified 70% methanol as solvent. For each sample three independent extracts were made, referred to as technical replicates. We have utilized HyStar v3.2 (Bruker Daltonics, Bremen, Germany) and DataAnalysis v4.1 (Bruker) for acquisition and ProfileAnalysis v2.1 (Bruker) for the analysis of the LC-UV/MS data. Acquisition and analysis of the LC-MS/MRM data has been performed by means of MassLynx v4.1 and TargetLynx v4.1 software (Waters, Eschborn, Germany).
keywords: metabolomics, potato, genotypes, anthocyanins, polyphenols
name: Metabolite profiling of red and blue potatoes revealed cultivar and tissue specific patterns for anthocyanins and other polyphenols (supplemental data files)

description: Barley high-confidence (HC) and low-confidence (LC) gene sequences (International Barley Sequencing Consortium, 2012) were mapped against the H. bulbosum assembly using BLAST (Altschul et al., 1990). Thresholds were set to a maximum e-value of 0, at least 90 % sequence identity and at minimum 300 bp alignment length. In cases of multiple hits, best hits were chosen considering e-value and bit-scores. The genetic map positions of the barley genes were taken from The International Barley Sequencing Consortium (International Barley Sequencing Consortium, 2012) and the population sequencing (POPSEQ) barley map (Mascher et al., 2013a).
keywords: Blast alignments, barley gene sequences, Hordeum bulbosum assembly
name: Blast alignments of barley gene sequences (IBSC, 2012) against H. bulbosum assembly

description:
This dataset contains the raw data for the publication: ‘D. Pflugfelder, R. Metzner, D. van Dusschoten, R. Reichel, S. Jahnke, R. Koller: Non-invasive imaging of plant roots in different soils using Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)’ submitted to Plant Methods.
Barley (Hordeum vulgare L. var Barke) plants (N=4) were cultivated in seven different substrates as detailed in the file ‘PlantIDs.xlsx’. Three weeks after sowing, the plant roots were imaged using MRI and subsequently harvested, scanned and analysed with WinRhizo. Both 3D MRI data and corresponding scanned images of the excavated roots are supplied.
MRI acquisition parameters: 
4.7T MRI equipped with a Varian console; Sequence: Spin Echo Multi-Slice (SEMS), TR=2850ms, Bandwidth BW=156kHz, Echo Time TE=9ms, two averages. Resolution: 0.5x0.5x1.0mm3. The 3D MRI data is supplied in the Nifti-file format, consisting of a header (*.hdr) and a data file (*.img). Furthermore, for each plant a maximum intensity projection is added as a preview image (*.tif).
keywords: MRI, 3D images, Barley, roots, Phenotyping
name: 3D Magnetic resonance images of three weeks old barley roots grown in different soils

description: H. bulbosum WGS contigs, which were not included in the high-density genetic maps at first instance were included into these frameworks by applying an approach that anchors markers into genetic bins of a framework map as described earlier (Mascher et al., 2013a). To do so, a nearest-neighbor search was performed to find the set of framework markers with minimal Hamming distance to a given SNP. SNPs were placed into the framework map using the program canchor as published (Mascher et al., 2013a). Subsequently, SNP markers were filtered using the R statistical environment (R Core Team, 2012) in order to keep only H. bulbosum contigs where the major chromosome is supported by >= 95 % of framework map markers and the standard deviation of cM positions was at maximum 3.
keywords: De novoassembly of Hordeum bulbosum, Framework genetic map integration
name: Integration of de novo assembled Hordeum bulbosum contigs into genetic framework maps

description: Parental genetic maps were calculated for H. bulbosum using the program JoinMap v4.1 (Van Ooijen, 2011) for each individual parental line. Markers were used that are heterozygous in one parent while being homozygous in the other (i.e. ABxAA). GBS SNPs were only considered if lying on a H. bulbosum assembly contig that could be anchored to a barley gene as described above. Markers and individuals were excluded from the analysis if they exhibited more than 10 % and 20 % missing data, respectively. A minimum LOD score of 14 was considered in order to separate the seven linkage groups. The resulting marker order of each map was compared to high-density genetic maps of barley (International Barley Sequencing Consortium, 2012; Mascher et al., 2013a).
keywords: Hordeum bulbosum, high-density genetic maps, anchoring information to barley
name: High-density genetic maps of H. bulbosum and anchoring information to barley

description: Cryopreservation offers a means to store living plant material for an extended period, and is used to maintain vegetatively-reproduced plants. The molecular basis of successful cryopreservation remains far from understood. To reveal the biology underlying cryopreservation, the shoot tips of the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana were subjected to a cryopreservation standard procedure, and a transcriptomic approach was taken to describe the subsequent cellular events which occurred in WT and a mutant lacking a functional copy of the transcription factor WRKY22. The Supplemental Dataset Filer comprises all detected GO terms in WT and KO shoot tips (Dataset 1), Hitlist of the most highly up- and down-regulated genes in WT and KO (Dataset 2), as well as the mothertable showing changes in the mRNA level of all annotated Arabidopsis transcripts (Dataset 3).
keywords: abiotic stress, biotic stress, stomatal aperture, transcriptomics, ultralow temperature
name: Adaptation to osmotic stress induced during Arabidopsis thaliana cryopreservation is regulated by WRKY22, a defense-related transcription factor

description:
Gene families were inferred using a phylogenomics approach utilizing the OrthoFinder software incorporating the predicted protein sequences from bread wheat (RefSeq Annotation v1.0), nine other grasses and four Viridiplantae genomes. Wheat sub-genomes were handled as independent taxa. Gene family expansions and contractions in either one of the wheat sub-genomes, the wheat A- or D-lineage or the wheat genome in general were inferred using a previously established phylogenomic approach. Log-transformed gene family sizes among the 10 grasses were compared using phylogenetic comparative one-way ANOVA correcting for phylogenetic interdependency using a species tree that was computed by coalescence analysis of 14,275 orthologue-only subfamily clades extracted from the gene family trees derived by OrthoFinder. To account for hexaploidy in the bread wheat genome, all three sub-genomes were treated as separate entities i.e. taxa. Gene family sizes were log-scaled. 1) gene_family_analysis_results.xlsx Microsoft Excel file with five sheets containing the results of an analysis for the expansion and contraction of gene families in the genome of bread wheat cultivar Chinese Spring. The fifth sheet provides further details on the contents of sheet 1 to 4. 2) Traits.orthologs.xlsx Microsoft Excel file with two sheets. First sheet provides a detailed description of the columns of sheet 2, which lists all Plant Trait ontology term associations for V1.0 loci, including the originally mapped ortholog and information whether they are part of an expanded or contracted gene family. For more details or questions, contact
Manuel.Spannagl@helmholtz-muenchen.de and Daniel.Lang@helmholtz-muenchen.de.
keywords: wheat, gene ontology, gene families, comparative genomics
name: Gene family expansion and contraction in the genome of bread wheat cv. Chinese Spring.

description: Single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) matrices for a diversity panel of barley (Hordeum vulgare L.) accessions belonging to the WHEALBI panel. Exome sequences that revealed substantial variation in the barley genepool were obtained and validated. Data were successfully derived for 403 genotypes from the WHEALBI research project (EU FP7 no. FP7-613556), comprising formally bred cultivars, landraces and wild barley lines. This source material represents a range of worldwide barley genetic diversity, assembled to quantify variation and explore adaptation, and possible breeding responses (http://www.whealbi.eu/). The reference genome sequence assembly of barley cv. Morex (Mascher et al. 2017, Nature [doi:10.1038/nature22043]) was used as a reference. More than 64 million SNPs were extracted from sequences, which after applying a quality criterion of at least 80 % of genotypes being represented at a SNP locus was reduced to just under 2.1 million SNPs. All seven of barley’s chromosomes (1H to 7H) were well covered, with a range of 262,014 (6H) to 334,501 (2H) polymorphisms and a median distance between SNPs of between 14 and 27 bp, although a few large gaps in coverage remained, especially close to centromeres. Further details can be read in Bustos-Korts et al. 2019, The Plant Journal.
keywords: barley, Hordeum vulgare, genetic diversity, next-generation sequencing, exome capture, single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), plant genetic resources
name: Single-nucleotide polymorphism matrices for 403 barley genotypes (WHEALBI diversity panel)

description: K-mer matrix of 305 lines of Aegilops tauschii, along with one tetraploid sample (AB donor of NIAB SHW). K-mers present in only one sample were not retained. The matrix is divided into 10 parts. The file “accessions.txt” contains the accession names and also specifies the order in which presence/absence of a k-mer is scored in the presence/absence matrix. This work has been done as a part of OWWC (http://www.openwildwheat.org/) project.
keywords: wheat, Aegilops tauschii, crop wild relative, presence absence variation, genome-wide association study, genome sequencing
name: K-mer matrix of OWWC Aegilops tauschii diversity panel

description: This Bionano optical map was generated on the Irys instrument and assembled/aligned using the IrysView software package. This dataset contains the components used in the assembly. The alignment is to the raw ('_v1') scaffolds, available in the assembly release, along with coordinate tables that derive the final pseudomolecules from the raw scaffolds.. Descriptions and formal specifications of the enclosed files including contig (.cmap) and alignment (.xmap) files are available at https://opticalmapping.info/tutorials/file-formats/, and the methods underlying the enclosed conflict file are given in the IrysView documentation. The enclosed readme file gives detailed information about each file.
keywords: Rye, Secale, cereale, Lo7, IRGSC, Genome, Optical, Irys, Optigs, Hybrid, CMAP, XMAP, BioNano
name: Bionano optical map contig and alignment files used to generate the 2019-2021 rye (Secale cereale L. inbred line 'Lo7') genome assembly release

description: This genome assembly of rye (Secale cereale L. inbred line 'Lo7') was produced by the International Rye Genome Consortium (IRGSC). This data package includes the pseudomolecules, three versions of the scaffolds, and a coordinate conversion table that relates the coordinates of each, where columns prefixed 'orig_' denote the raw scaffolds ('v1'), 'scaffold' denotes the scaffolds after curating for chimeras ('v2'), and 'ss' or 'superscaffold' denotes the final set of scaffolds ('v3') arranged in the agp to produce the pseudomolecules.
keywords: Rye, Secale, cereale, Lo7, IRGSC, Assembly, Genome
name: The 2019-2021 rye (Secale cereale L. inbred line 'Lo7') genome assembly

description: The 2019-2021 IRGSC rye (Secale cereale L. inbred line 'Lo7') genome assembly release was constructed based upon chromosome sorted shotgun (CSS) data, Hi-C, Bionano Optical Mapping, and genetic mapping of the RIL population 'Lo7' x 'Lo225', adopted from the work of Bauer et. al. (2017; doi:10.1111/tpj.13436). The sources were used as the basis of intensive manual curation to produce a near optimum scaffold arrangement in the final pseudomolecules. These high-resolution images show the output of this suite of visualisations on the final assembly.
keywords: Rye, Secale, cereale, Lo7, IRGSC, Assembly, Genome, Visual, Plots, Suite
name: A suite of visual representations of the 2019-2021 rye (Secale cereale L. inbred line 'Lo7') genome assembly release

description:
RNA-interference is described as an evolutionary conserved, host defense mechanism against viral infection. Up to now only minor effort was taken to investigate the relevance of this mechanism for clearance of the SARS-CoV-2 RNA virus in infected individuals.

Small circulating RNAs were investigated from serum samples of COVID-19 patients.  Small RNAs were analyzed by high throughput sequencing from five mild cases, five severe cases and two control samples.  

Here, we profile the plasma of patients with mild and severe COVID-19 for the presence of small circulating RNAs during active and convalescene using high throughput sequencing. As result the presence of SARS-CoV-2 derived small RNAs in serum samples of mild and severe COVID-19 cases is described.
keywords: COVID-19, RNAi, SARS-CoV2, circulating-miRNA, small RNA
name: Severe cases of COVID-19 are associated with changes in circulating small RNA abundance.
